intro: Abronia fragrans var. harrisii, commonly known as the Harris's sweetshrub, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Geraniaceae family and is characterized by its aromatic, fragrant leaves and showy, pinkish-white flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, well-drained soils in woodland or swampy habitats. Its compact growth habit and seasonal blooming make it a distinctive addition to native plant gardens. The variety harrisii is distinguished by its specific geographic distribution and unique floral characteristics.

This variety thrives in sandy soils along the shorelines and dunes of the Pacific coast. It is commonly found in areas with mild, Mediterranean climates characterized by warm, dry summers and cool, wet winters. The plant is adapted to withstand salt spray and is often seen growing in association with other coastal flora. Its distribution is limited to these specific habitats, making it a rare and localized species.
